foliation.note: Folio numbers 78, 139, 140, 141, 142 assigned to leaves no longer present in the volume (as per historic foliation practice at Cambridge University Library).
Numbering in pencil in the upper right-hand corner of the rectos, by H.L. PinkPink, H. L..

collation.p: At its core, the manuscript comprises two codicological units (Quires 3-10 and 11-15). Additional quires were inserted at the front (Quire 2) and at the back (Quires 16-17), and which were of different but presumably near-contemporary production. The same style of formal bookhand is used at both ends (though by more than one hand), and since the additions at the back begin on what must have been initially blank leaves at the end of Quire 15 it seems likely that these were always intended to be bound with the core quires of the manuscript. Another quire (Quire 1) was added to the front of the manuscript; though the subject-matter of its contents fits with the rest of the manuscript, its markedly different production and on a standalone quire suggests that it was a subsequent addition, and so the manuscript has been catalogued as a composite. The 15th-century additions to the endleaves, however, point to the parts of the manuscript having been bound together at a fairly early stage.

signatures.p: Modern quire numbers in pencil throughout. These are not followed in the formula given above and elsewhere in this description.

note.p: Addition of a Sufrage to St Egwin of Evesham added to f. 143r (see Part 2 for further details).
Collation formula by the hand of H.L. Pink on the inside of the rear cover).

binding.p: Rebound in June 1961 by Douglas Cockerell and Son in Letchworth, according to a note inside the upper cover. Brown quarter leather and marbled paper covering over millboards, with plain pastedowns. The classmark and title Miscellanea are tooled on the spine in gold. Labels from a previous binding - including a strip of red Russia leather with the gold-stamped title: Tractatus M.S. and scraps onto which are printed the current classmark - are pasted inside the upper board.
Binding height: 270 mm, width: 160 mm, depth: 40 mm.

provenance.p: Richard Colingburne (fl. c. 1450-1550) Colingburne, Richard, fl. c. 1450-1550 : his ownership inscription on f. 1v: Ricardus Colynburne me possidit.

Perhaps owned by John Moore (1646-1714), bishop of Ely Moore, John, 1646-1714 : but not recorded in Bernard, Catalogi librorum manuscriptorum Angliæ et Hiberniæ (c. 1697) nor in the handwritten supplementary list of Moore's manuscripts, now CUL MS Oo.7.50.2, compiled by Thomas Tanner (1674-1735) after the publication of Bernard's catalogue (see the modern pencil notes on the inside cover and on f. 2r: Possibly Bishop Moore's, but not included in any list of his MSS. - C.S. (i.e. Charles Sayle).

history.acquisition: Given the uncertainty surrounding Moore's ownership of this manuscript, the insertion on the inside front cover of the donation bookplate engraved by John Pine Pine, John, 1690-1756 in 1736 cannot be taken at face value as evidence of the presentation of the manuscript to the University Library in 1715 by George I George I, King of Great Britain, 1660-1727 .

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on Margaret Connolly, Manuscripts in the University Library, Cambridge (Dd-Oo), The Index of Middle English Prose (Woodbridge: Brewer, 2009) an unpublished description of the manuscript composed between 1926 and 1930 by M.R. James James, M.R. (Montague Rhodes), 1862-1936, now held in the University Archives (UA ULIB 7/3/74).

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card. For information on eligibility and admissions procedures, see Joining the Library). For further information on the availability of the manuscript, please contact the Manuscripts Reading Room.

msItem.title: Tractatus de summa Paenitentiae
msItem.incipit: 2v: [P]eniteas cito peccator cum sit miserator / Judex et sunt hec quinque tenenda tibi
msItem.explicit: 6v: Confitemini domino quoniam bonus sed dominus nec in fide nec in laude peccatis dei confiteri sed tantomodo in laude
msItem.note: A theological poem with prose commentary that has been variously attributed to Peter of Blois Peter, of Blois, approximately 1135-approximately 1212, John of Garland John, of Garland, approximately 1195–approximately 1272, and William de Montibus William, de Montibus, approximately 1140–1213.

msItem.author: Mikołaj (Nicholas) Venatoris, Suffragan Bishop of Siret (1413-?1434)
msItem.title: Compendium de modo confitendi
msItem.incipit: 6v Prima confitens debet confiteri de peccatis cordis, oris et operis, cogitacionis, omissionis et commissionis
msItem.explicit: 8r Hoc compendium factum est per reverendum in Christo patre domini episcopum gerecensem sacre pagine doctorem cognomine veneracionis nacione ungaria ad peticionem magnifici principis domini Nicholai de gahara ipsius regni ungaris comitis palacini et vicarii generalis
msItem.note: Added in the late 15th or early 16th century.

msItem.title: Confession formula
msItem.incipit: 8r Confiteor deo beate Marie omnibus sanctis et tibi pater quia peccavi nimis
msItem.explicit: 8v Gula per gulam peccavi gustando odorando tangendo lante properanter

p.secFol: 3r et deserat et in alijs graviter per duret

layout.seg: Not ruled. Single columns. 30-32 lines to the page.

handNote.p: This part of the manuscript is written by a single scribe in a cursive script with both Anglicana and Secretary features (e.g. single- and double-compartment 'a').

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, University Library, MS Mm.6.17, ff. 9r-138v, 143r-144v

msItem.author: Guigo II
msItem.title: Scala Claustralium
msItem.rubric: 9r Scala claustralium [added title]
msItem.incipit: 9r Cum die quadam corporali manuum labore occupatus
msItem.explicit: 12v et adolescentulis adherebit Delicatus est sponsus iste nobilis est
msItem.finalRubric: 12v Explicit liber qui dicitur Scala claustra

msItem.author: Edmund of Abingdon
msItem.title: Speculum ecclesiae
msItem.rubric: 13r Incipit liber sancti Edmundi confessoris qui nuncupatur speculum ecclesie
msItem.incipit: 13r [I]n nomine domini altissimi dulcissimi nostri ihesu Christi hic incipiunt materie que tanguntur in sermone sequente ruditer dictato ad evitandum curiositatem ne quis dimittat sanctitatem propter curiosam loquelam exteriorem
msItem.explicit: 12v Qui cum deo patre et spiritu sancto vivit et regnat deus per omnia secula seculorum Amen
msItem.finalRubric: 12v Explicit tractatus beati Edmundi de Pontiniaco qui appellatur Speculum ecclesie

msItem.author: Pseudo-Augustine
msItem.title: Liber exhortationis ad quemdam comitem seu De salutaribus documentis
msItem.rubric: 34v Incipit epistola beati Augustini ad Julianum comitem
msItem.incipit: 34v O mi frater si cupias scire quamvis ego nesciam quam perfectissima
msItem.explicit: 92v sed exultantdo et laudando suscipis in eterna beatudine una cum sanctis et electis tuis eternaliter regnare concedis quia est et tibi cum eterno patre et spiritu sancto vna deitas gloria virtus imperium et potestatas in secula seculorum. Amen
msItem.finalRubric: 60v Explicit epistola beati Augustini episcopi ad Julianum comitem

msItem.author: Richard Rolle
msItem.title: Iudica me deus
msItem.rubric: 60v Incipit capitulum de Judicio dei secundum Hampole
msItem.incipit: 60v [I]udica me deus et discerne causam meam de gente non sancta: A deo qui scrutatur cor et renes volo iudicari non ab homine qui solummodo videt ea que exterius apparent
msItem.explicit: 71r Sic in operibus Christi laudem et gloriam querite vt post hanc vitam ad regnum Christi valeatis peruenire Amen

msItem.title: Regula Heremitarum
msItem.rubric: 71v Incipit Regula Heremitarum
msItem.incipit: 71v [H]eremita dicitur quis ab hereo quod est manere quasi herens mite vel pocius ab heremo in quo semotus a turbis viuere debet solus
msItem.explicit: 77v Si apostoli habentes potestatem de evangelio vivere laborabant manibus suis ne quem gravarent cur tu in usus tuos neccessaria non praepares vel fiscellam texemento vel canistrum lentis plecto viminibus texantur et lina capiendis piscibus scribantur et libri vt et manus operetur et anima leccione saturetur. In desiderijs nempe est omnis ociosus

msItem.title: Sermon on Judgment Day
msItem.note: The sermon consists of three separate works

msItem.author: ? Augustine
msItem.title: Tractatus de miseria hominis
msItem.rubric: 79r De die Judicij secundum
msItem.incipit: 79r [F]ratres karissimi quam tremenda est dies illa in qua Christus redemptor omnium veniet cum flamma ignis qui inflammabit adversarios suos
msItem.explicit: 88r Esto igitur bonus tu qui mala despicis quia si malus remanes deus male malum perdet

msItem.author: Pseudo-Augustine
msItem.title: Sermo de bonis celi et de miseria inferni
msItem.incipit: 88r [H]omo qui laboras gloriam querendo terrenam vanam et lubricam tibi arridentem fallaciter blandientem fieri posset
msItem.explicit: 89v ad melius studium vos prouocet amor glorie
msItem.note: According to Weidmann (2011), p. 242 fn. 34, this is a typical English sermon that largely consists of Pseudo-Augustine's De triplici habitaculo and the Elucidarium of Honorius von Autun.

msItem.author: Caesarius of Arles
msItem.title: De igne purgatorio
msItem.incipit: 89v In leccione apostolica que vobis paulo aute recitata est fratres karissimi audiuimus apostolum dicentem quia fundamentum aliud nemo ponere potest
msItem.explicit: 92v sicut iam sepe dixi quodcumque possumus euadere et minuta sine quibus esse non possumus amore inimicorum et elemosinarum largitate redimere Prestante domino nostro ihesu Christo. Amen
msItem.finalRubric: 92v Explicit tractatus de die Judicij secundum

msItem.title: Quandocumque tribularis: two linked passages on temptation from the Ancrene Wisse and The Chastising of God's Children
msItem.incipit: 92v Quicumque tribularis vel temptaris memento huius remedij
msItem.explicit: 93r Sic nos dominus dimittit ad horam et subtrahit gratiam suam consolamen et solacium a nobis

note.p: A previously unidentified copy of Quandocumque tribularis, two linked passages on temptation that are integrated into both the Ancrene Wisse and The Chastising of God's Children, but this Latin piece also circulated as a separate work. Previously, five manuscript copies of the text had been identified [see Colledge and Bazire (1957), p. 260]. This sixth version, like the other copies, has retained the child's exclamation in English: dame dame.
The text has now been edited in Strub (2024).

msItem.title: Tract on bishops and bribery from the Decretum Gratiani
msItem.rubric: 93r Episcopi non debent aliquid accipere a presbiteris vel clericis Capitulo xvj.q.j.

msItem.explicit: 93r et cum apparuerit princeps pastorum percipietis inmarcescibilem glorie coronam

msItem.title: Tract on almsgiving, perhaps excerpted from the Decretum Gratiani
msItem.rubric: 93r De generibus elemosinarum Distinctio xlv
msItem.incipit: 93r Tria sunt genera elemosinarum
msItem.explicit: 93r et errantes in viam reducere veritatis

msItem.title: Tract on almsgiving, perhaps excerpted from the Decretum Gratiani
msItem.rubric: 93r Item Augustinus
msItem.incipit: 93v Due sunt elemosine. una cordis alia pecunie
msItem.explicit: 93v si sine benigno corde tribuitur omnino non sufficit

msItem.title: Untitled tract on greed, perhaps excerpted from Jacobus de Voragine's Legenda Aurea
msItem.author: Jacobus de Voragine
msItem.incipit: 93v Nota quod sex sunt que nos ab immoderato diuiciarum appetitu debent retrahare
msItem.explicit: 93v Et alterius que est in perdicione duplicis boni .scilicet. boni in presenti quod est gracia; et boni in futuro. quod est eterna gloria
msItem.note: The same opening line occurs in Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS Ashmole 751.

msItem.title: Collection of theological sayings
msItem.incipit: 93v Melius est homini viam veritatis non agnoscere quam post agnitam retroire
msItem.explicit: 94r Qui enim iactanter orat laudem appetendo humanam non solum eius oratio non delet peccata sed ipsa vertitur in peccatum
msItem.note: Few excerpts contain rubrics, including: De fide, De spe, De caritate, leo papa.

msItem.author: Pseudo-Bernard
msItem.title: Meditationes piissimae de cognitione humanae conditionis (excerpt)
msItem.rubric: 93r Bernardus in meditacionibus
msItem.incipit: 94r Multi multa sciunt et semetipsos nesciunt
msItem.explicit: 94v Et ita per cognicionem mei ascendam ad cognicionem dei

msItem.title: Untitled tract on almsgiving and other works of mercy
msItem.rubric: 93r Ambrosius
msItem.incipit: 94v Rogo vos fratres vt attencius cogitetis quare Christiani vocatis estis et quare crucem Christi in fronte portetis
msItem.explicit: 94v Et est quasi ille qui de antea clave firmat vasculum: in quo putridas paleas habet inclusas etcaetera

msItem.title: Poem on the purpose of reading, perhaps based on a similar poem in the Ordinaturus Magister (an apparatus to the Decretum Gratiani)
msItem.incipit: 94v Aliqui legunt ut sciant et hic est superbia
msItem.explicit: 94v Quidam ut edificent et hic est caritas

msItem.title: Note against hunters from the Decretum Gratiani
msItem.incipit: 94v Nota contra venatores. distinctio lxxxvj
msItem.explicit: 94v Numquam vidimus venatorem esse sanctum

msItem.title: Note on bishops and bribery from the Decretum Gratiani
msItem.incipit: 94v Episcopi non debent aliquid accipere a presbiteris vel clericis Capitulo xvj. q.j.

msItem.title: Theological saying, perhaps excerpted from Bonaventure's Soliloquium de quatuor mentalibus exercitiis
msItem.rubric: 93r Augustinus
msItem.incipit: 94v Qui enim crescit in scientia et non crescit in bona vita elongatur a Deo

msItem.author: Johannes Wyclif
msItem.title: Tract on simony
msItem.rubric: 94v De symonia
msItem.incipit: 94v Quando enim quis pro pecunia celebrat vel ministrat in officio in quo spiritus sanctus datur nedum facit pecuniam deum suum sed ambas personas immolat idolo quod sic honorat
msItem.explicit: 95r Hoc doctor euangelicus tractatu de symonia . capitulo primo

msItem.author: Caesarius of Arles
Pseudo-Augustine
msItem.title: Excerpt from sermon 222 [Sermon 220 of Pseudo-Augustine]
msItem.incipit: 95r Nemo habet iniustum lucrum sine iusto dampno. ubi lucrum ibi dampnum, lucrum in archa. dampnum in consciencia
msItem.explicit: 95r Si enim diem mortis sue cogitare iugiter vellent; animos suos ab omni cupiditate et malicia cohiberent

msItem.author: Bede the Venerable
msItem.title: Excerpt from Homiliae 1.13: In dominica secunda post Epiphaniam
msItem.incipit: 95r Bona est castitas coniugalis, melior continencia vidualis, optima perfectio virginalis

msItem.title: Five biblical riddles with solutions in the tradition of the Solomon and Saturn and Adrian and Ritheus dialogues
msItem.incipit: 95r Quis fuit natus et non mortuus . scilicet Enoc et Helyas
msItem.explicit: 95r Quis fuit semel natus et bis mortuus . scilicet Jonas et Lazarus

msItem.author: Remigius of Auxerre
msItem.title: Dicta sancti Augustini in prologo psalterii et aliorum de virtutibus psalmorum [excerpt from the Enarrationes in Psalmos]
msItem.incipit: 95r Canticum psalmorum animas decorat inuitat angelos in adiutorium, effugat demones, reuocat sanctitatem omni peccatori, delet peccata, dominum placat, diabolum effudit, voluntates illicitas extinguit, asperitatem eicit, furorem deprimit, iracundiam frangit
msItem.explicit: 95r Laus dei est quam qui in corde retinet post exitum babilonis in celesti ierusalem gaudebit

msItem.author: Peter Lombard
msItem.title: Sententiarum IV libri (excerpt)
msItem.rubric: 95v Augustinus
msItem.incipit: 95v Mentiri Deo potes, sed ipsum fallere non potes
msItem.explicit: Intus enim te inspicit et examinat

msItem.author: Peter Chrysologus
msItem.title: Sermo 8 and 42 (excerpts)
msItem.rubric: 95v Petrus Rauenensis in quodam sermone de Jeiunio
msItem.incipit: 95v Manus pauperis Abrahe sinus est, ubi quicquid pauper acciperit, mox reponit
msItem.explicit: Misericordiam qui non dat alteri tollit sibi. Misericordia sibi erit qui sparget pauperi

msItem.author: ? Augustine of Hippo
msItem.title: Sermon on Penance [Sermo 117]
msItem.rubric: 95v Sermo sancti augustini episcopi de penitencia
msItem.incipit: 95v [R]ogo vos fratres karissimi, videte qualis debet esse penitencia
msItem.explicit: 95v Nunc itaque exultemus in domino: gaudeamus cum fletu, memores simus dignacionis diuine et captiuitatis nostre etcaetera

msItem.author: ? Augustine of Hippo
msItem.title: Sermon on abstinence [Sermo 147]
msItem.rubric: 97v Sermo sancti Augustini episcopi de veteri et nouo testamento et primum de Abstinencia quadragesimali
msItem.incipit: 97v [S]icut dicit euangelista abstinuisse dominum quadraginta diebus ac noctibus in deserto
msItem.explicit: 98v Hoc est non cogitemus aliud nisi celestis regni dominum et future resurrectionis auctorem, prestante domino nostro ihesu Christo qui viuit et regnat deus per omnia secula seculorum Amen

msItem.author: Pseudo-Augustine
Geoffroy Babion
msItem.title: Sermon on penance [Sermo 393]
msItem.rubric: 99r Sermo sancti Augustini episcopi penitencia
msItem.incipit: 99r [P]enitentes, penitentes penitentes, Si tamen estis penitentes et non estis irridentes mutate vitam reconsiliamini deo
msItem.explicit: 100v Dum viuis age veram penitenciam: ut cum veneris in iudicium dei. non ab eo confudaris sed ab eo in regnum ducaris cum ipsius adiutorio; qui cum deo patre et sancto spiritu regnat dominator omni per infinita secula seculorum. Amen

listBibl.bibl: CPL284, now ascribed to Geoffroy Babion, ed. PL 39: 1713–15

msItem.author: John Cassian
msItem.title: Collationes, Pars II, Decima Quinta, Caput VIII-Caput IX(
msItem.incipit: 100v [E]t re uera maius miraculum est de propria carne fomitem eradicare luxurie quam expellere immundos spiritus de corporibus alienis
msItem.explicit: 100v Et idcirco monentur vt ex hac parte nichil sibi beatitudinis aut glorie audeant vendicare, que dei tantum potencia ac virtute perficitur, sed ex illa vitae sue cordisque intima puritate, ob quam nomina eorum inscribi merentur in coelis.

msItem.author: John Chrysostom
msItem.title: Homilia de muliere Cananaea
msItem.rubric: 100v Vltima pars cuiusdam sermonis sancti Johannis episcopi de muliere chananea de finibus suis egressa
msItem.incipit: 101r [O] mulier, Deus dicit. O mulier. Audiant hec qui iactantur orant et fastidiose precantur
msItem.explicit: 102v Pro hijs omnibus gracias agamus deo per Christum dominum nostrum: cum quo est deo patri vna cum sancto spiritu honor gloria et potestas per immortalia secula seculorum Amen

msItem.author: John Chrysostom
Pseudo-John Chrysostom
msItem.title: De cruce domini extra ciuitatem (title from other copy)
msItem.rubric: 102v Vltima pars cuiusdam sermonis sancti Johannis episcopi in parastene de virtute sancte crucis
msItem.incipit: 102v [E]t si nosse desideras karissime virtutemcurcies, et quanta possum ad eius laudem dicere
msItem.explicit: 104v Sicut gracio preuaricacio per lignum: ita et salus per lignum. Pro hijs autem omnibus gratias agamus deo: per Christum dominum nostrum Amen

msItem.author: Haimo of Auxerre
msItem.title: In epistolam Pauli ad Galatas, cap. V
msItem.rubric: 104v Exposicio epistole beati Pauli apostoli ad Galathas (extract)
msItem.incipit: 104v [F]ratres, Spiritu ambulate; et desideria carnis non perficietis etcaetera De hac leccione diuersi doctores non equaliter senciunt, dicentes quidam de spiritu hominis locutum hic apostolum esse
msItem.explicit: 105r Et econtra spiritus concupiscit caro aduersus carnem; quia ille delectatur ieiunijs abstinencia castitate et hijs que carni contraria sunt etcaetera

msItem.author: Pope Gregory I
msItem.title: Homilia XXXI [from the Homiliae XL in Evangelia]
msItem.rubric: 105r Quedam extraccio posterioris partis omelie beati Gregorij pape super illud euangelium Erat ihesus docens in sinagoga eorum sabbatis
msItem.incipit: 105r [E]rat autem docens in sinagoga eorum sabbatis.
msItem.explicit: 106v Nec mora erit in fletibus; quia tergent cicuis transeuntes lacrimas gaudia mansura. Prestante domino nostro ihesu Christo: cui cum patre et spiritu sancto honor et imperium per omnia secula seculorum

msItem.author: Pope Gregory I
msItem.title: Homilia XXXVIII [from the Homiliae XL in Evangelia]
msItem.rubric: 106v Extraccio cuiusdam partis omelie beati Gregorij pape super illud euangelium Simile est regnum celorum homini regi qui fecit nupcias filio suo etcaetera
msItem.incipit: 106v [M]ulti sunt vocati, pauci vero electi. Tremendum est valde fratres karissimi, quod audiuimu
msItem.explicit: 107r Sed quia nonnunquam mentes audiencium plus exempla fidelium quam docencium verba conuertunt, volo vobis aliquid de proximo dicere, quod corda vestra tanto formidolosius audiant, quanto eis hoc de propinquo sonat etcaetera

msItem.author: Augustine of Hippo
msItem.title: Sermo 83 (extract)
msItem.rubric: 107r Extraccio ex omelia sancti Augustini episcopi super illud euangelium Silem est regnum celorum homini regi qui voluit raccioni ponere cum seruis suis etcaetera
msItem.incipit: 108r [S]ic inquit et pater meus celestis faciet vobis, si non remiseritis unusquisque vestrum fratribus vestris
msItem.explicit: 108r Ait enim: Donantes vobismetipsis si quis aduersus aliquem habet querelam, sicut deus in Christo donauit vobis etcaetera

msItem.author: Ambrosiaster
msItem.title: In Epistolam ad Colossenses
msItem.rubric: 108r Exposicio epistole beati Pauli apostoli ad thesalonicenses
msItem.incipit: 108r [F]ratres non cessamus pro vobis orantes et postulantes, ut impleamini agnicione voluntatis eius
msItem.explicit: 108v Nam sine fide Christi nullus egressus de inferno est, quia obligatus peccatis exire ianuas tartari non potest

msItem.author: ? Augustine of Hippo
msItem.title: Sermo 53
msItem.rubric: 108v Dicta sancti Augustini episcopi contra detractores
msItem.incipit: 108v [Q]vando enim veniet dominus deus noster, non silebit Arguam te.
msItem.explicit: 109r Ipsa tamen triduo ideona fuit conuerti orare plangere et de pena imminenti miscericordiam promereri

msItem.author: Augustine of Hippo
msItem.title: Sermo 84
msItem.rubric: 109v Sermo sancti Augustini episcopi de vera et beata vita
msItem.incipit: 109v [D]ixit dominus cuidam adolescenti. Si vis venire ad vitam, serua mandata
msItem.explicit: Si enim mercedem amamus in opere non deficiamus, et ineternum cum Christo regnabimus

msItem.author: Augustine of Hippo
msItem.title: Sermo 93
msItem.rubric: 110r Dicta sancti Augustini episcopi super illud euangelium. Simile est regnum celorum decem virginibus etcaetera
msItem.incipit: 110v [E]cce virgo, ecce habet lampades
msItem.explicit: 112r Non consulencium sed irridencium est responsio. Quare irridencium. Quia sapientes erant, quia sapientia erat in illis etcaerea

msItem.title: Tract on St Peter
msItem.rubric: 112r Dicta sancti Augustini in cathedra sancti Petri
msItem.incipit: 112r [P]etrus respexit dominus lacrimantem, et apertis oculis eius emendauit errorem
msItem.explicit: 113r Et qui ante lacrimas preuaricator extitit, post lacrimas assumptus est: et alios regendos accepit, qui prius semetipsum non rexit, prestante domino nostro qui cum patre et spiritu sancto viuit et regnat per omnia secula seculorum Amen
msItem.note: The first half of the tract corresponds with Sermo 76 from Maximus of Turin's Collectio sermonum antiqua [CCSL 23] while the second part occurs in William of Ockham's Dialogus, Part 3, tract 1, book 4, Chapter 3 [ed. Kilcullen and others (2011)]. However, the work as a whole also occurs in Ambrose's Feria III. Hebdomadae Sanctae [see Sancti Ambrosii, Mediolanensis Episcopi, Opera Omnia (1886), pp. 67-68].

msItem.title: Tract on prayer for the dead
msItem.rubric: 113r Dicta Bede presbiteri quomodo debemus orare pro caris nostris mortuis
msItem.incipit: 112r Anime autem sancte que in hoc seculo iam penitencie satisfaccione purgate a saluatore nostro recipiuntur, cum eoesse credende sunt
msItem.explicit: 113r sicut scriptum est Carissimi que sursum sunt sapite non que super terram, vt nos huius clauigeri regni celestis fulti suffragijs ad Christum dominum nostrum cum eo in eternum mansuri peruenire possitis cui honor et potestas in vnitate deitatus eiusdemque in trinitate personarum per omnia secula seculorum. Amen
msItem.note: Edited as part as a possible sermon [Sermo 191] of Augustine of Hippo in PL 39: 2101-2102.

msItem.title: Collection of Proverbs from the books of Proverbs, Ecclesiastes, Wisdom, Ecclesiasticus, and Tobit
msItem.rubric: 114r Salamon in proverbiijs
msItem.incipit: 112r Dies autem quibus regnauit david super israel quadraginta anni in hebron regnauit septem annis in ierusalem triginta tribus
msItem.explicit: 113r Bona est oracio cum ieiunio et elemosina magis quam thesauros auri condere quoniam elimosina a morte liberat et ipsa est que purgat peccata et facit invenire vitam eternam

msItem.author: Augustine
msItem.title: De uidendo deo [Epistola 147] (extract)
msItem.rubric: 118r Primo: Augustinus ad paulinam de uidendo deo
msItem.incipit: 112r Nos enim iam secundum carnem non nouimus Christum sed secundum spiritum. Spiritus enim ante faciem nostram Christus dominus qui nos in omnem plenitudinem dei misericordia sua implere dignetur ut uideri possit a nobis
msItem.explicit: 113r alios regendos accepit . qui prius seipsum non rexit ; prestante domino deo qui cum patre et spiritu sancto viuit et regnat per omnia secula seculorum Amen

msItem.author: Augustine of Hippo
msItem.title: Epistola 148 (extract)
msItem.rubric: 118r Secundo: Augustinus itaque ad fortunacianum
msItem.incipit: 112r Beati mundo corde quoniam ipsi deum videbunt Beatissimus quoque athanasius alexandrinus episcopus cum ageret aduersus arrianos
msItem.explicit: 113r Que uox apostoli immo eius per apstolum Christi est et illa non repudientur testimonia scripturarum quibus deus visus esse narratur quia et inuisiblis est per proriam deitatis naturam et cum uult uideri potest per assumptam sicut placuerit creaturam

msItem.title: 1st Epistle of St John, Chapter 4 (quotations of 1 John 4:12 and 1 John 4:16)
msItem.rubric: 118v Johannes in epistola
msItem.incipit: 118v Deum nemo vidit umquam lectio prima et capitulo xv
msItem.explicit: 118v Et in alia lectio Deus caritas est et qui manet in caritate in deo manet et deus in eo

msItem.author: Isidore of Seville
msItem.title: Consilia Isidori [epitome of the second book of Isidore of Seville, Synonyma]
msItem.incipit: 118v [O] homo scito temetipsum scito quid sis scito cur ortus sis quare natus sis
msItem.explicit: 124r O homo nichil gracio facias propter laudem humanam nichil propter temporalem operacionem, sed omnia propter vitam eternam. Ad quam nos perducat, qui sine fine viuit et regnat Amen

msItem.author: William of Rymyngton
msItem.title: Meditationes siue Stimulus peccatoris (Excerpts: Part I, Chapters I-III)
msItem.incipit: 124r [M]emento miser homo quod cuius es et incinerem reuerteris et ut hoc clarius consideres memento frequncius condicionis triplicis status tui
msItem.explicit: 127r Assit pijssime domine deus ut preualeat nequicia peccatoris et dolent sine omnipotentes ex quo

msItem.author: Pseudo-Richard Rolle of Hampole
msItem.title: De XII utilitatibus tribulationis
msItem.rubric: 127r Hampul de tribulacione
msItem.incipit: 127r O Anima tribulata et temptata tibi verbum istud proponitur ut discas de quo tribulaciones deseruiunt et ut eas non solum pacienter
msItem.explicit: 138v Aliter non potes in regnum celorum intrare dicente apostolo: per multas tribulaciones oportes nos intrare in regnum celorum. Quod nobis concedat qui sine fine viuit et regnat. Amen

msItem.title: Suffrage to St Egwin of Evesham
msItem.incipit: 143r Recolentes celebremus patris nostri festa Egwyne qui hac luce fruens multis claruit miraculis ad postremum sociatus ciuibus ethereis
msItem.explicit: 143r Deus qui hodierna die beati Egwyni confessoris tui atque pontificis animam ad eterna gaudia transtulisti, da nobis eius precibus illuc humiliter tendere, quo pastor gloriosus ducente praecessit Per Christum dominum nostrum Amen
msItem.note: The suffrage is from the proper office of the feast of the deposition of St Egwin, as found in the Evesham Breviary (now Oxford, Bodleian Library, Barlow 41).

msItem.title: Advice based on 1 John 2:15
msItem.incipit: 143r Qui amat Christum mundum non diligit istum
msItem.note: Full transcription; the line also occurs in the Vision of Piers Plowman

msItem.title: Medical recipe for migraine
msItem.rubric: 143rFor þe migryn
msItem.incipit: 143r tacke olibam wheet flowre peper cumyn lyke myth made yn powder
msItem.explicit: 143r then make a lytyll plaster ther off and ley hyt ther as the peyn ys
msItem.note: Added by a late 15th- or early 16th-century hand [the same hand that added the next recipe].

msItem.title: Medical recipe for unidentified purpose
msItem.rubric: 143rFor [? ssori]
msItem.incipit: 143r Take alysandre parcely violettes sowr dok and whet brod a handfull of all these herbes and stem them in a mort[...]
msItem.explicit: 143r and take iij sponfull of þe just and putt it in posset alle and drynke v mornynges
msItem.note: Added by a late 15th- or early 16th-century hand [the same hand that added the previous recipe].

layout.seg: Ruled in leadpoint, frame only. Single columns. 30-33 lines to the page, written below top line.

handNote.p: The core part of the manuscript (Quires 3-10 and 11-14 and the first three leaves of Quire 15) was written by a single scribe in a formal, semi-textualis bookhand.
Quires 2, the rest of Quire 15 and Quires 16-17 were written by several hands, each executing a form of Northern Gothica Textualis.
Added medical recipes on ff. 143r are written in a current Secretary script.

decoNote.p: Two-line red initials, in Quires 2 and 17 only.
One-line capitals highlighted in red throughout.
Headings rubricated in red ink throughout.

change.persName: Dr Clarck Drieshen, Project Cataloguer in Curious Cures in Cambridge Libraries, Cambridge University Library
